lessonPlans.title: Effects of Human Behavior and Communication on the Learning Process
objectives: Understand how human behavior affects learning and motivation
Identify defense mechanisms and emotional reactions in students
Apply effective communication techniques during instruction

lessonPlans.overview: This lesson explores the psychological foundations of flight instruction. Understanding human behavior is critical for effective teaching, as each student brings unique motivations, fears, and learning patterns. This lesson covers Maslow's Hierarchy of Needs, defense mechanisms, emotional reactions, and communication barriers that instructors must recognize and address.

lessonPlans.title: Normal Takeoff and Climb
objectives: Apply power smoothly and maintain directional control ±5° heading deviation
Rotate at proper speed ±5 knots of VX or VY as appropriate
Establish and maintain VY climb ±5 knots
Demonstrate proper crosswind technique for wind conditions
references: FAA-H-8083-25 Pilot's Handbook of Aeronautical Knowledge
prerequisites: Student can identify and explain VX, VY, and V speeds
Student has completed preflight and before takeoff checks
Weather is within student proficiency limits
lessonPlans.overview: The normal takeoff is the foundation of all takeoff procedures. This lesson covers the coordination of power application, elevator control, rudder inputs, and precise airspeed control. Crosswind techniques are integrated from the beginning, as purely calm wind conditions are rare. Students learn to sequence their attention between attitude, airspeed, and directional control while simultaneously teaching a student.

instructorActions: Review: 'What is VY? Why is it important after takeoff?'
Instruct: 'Draw takeoff phases on whiteboard: Ground roll, Rotation, Initial climb, Climb to pattern altitude' with specific examples
Demonstrate: 'Demonstrate with model airplane: Control positions during ground roll' while explaining each step
Explain: 'During ground roll, ailerons control wind drift, rudder controls direction'
Instruct: 'Show POH takeoff performance chart - calculate takeoff distance together' with specific examples
Discuss crosswind component: 'If wind is 270° at 12 knots and runway is 240°, what's the crosswind?'
Brief clearly: 'common errors: Late rotation, climbing too steeply, poor directional control'
studentActions: Calculate crosswind component using E6B or mental math
keyPoints: VY provides the best rate of climb - use it to clear obstacles quickly
Maintain centerline with rudder, not ailerons
Rotation speed is typically 60-70 knots for trainers
Crosswind correction starts on ground roll, continues through climb

instructorActions: Narrate every action: 'Clearing the area... checking final... aligning with centerline'
Smoothly advance throttle to full: 'Accelerating... monitoring engine instruments'
Call out: 'Airspeed alive... right rudder to counteract P-factor and torque'
At rotation speed: 'Rotate to climb attitude... feel for liftoff'
After liftoff: 'Positive rate... maintaining runway heading... accelerating to VY'
At VY: 'Pitch to maintain 79 knots... trimming... continuing climb'
Instruct: 'Complete after-takeoff checklist while maintaining VY ±5 knots' with specific examples
keyPoints: Smooth, continuous control inputs - no jerky movements
Eyes outside during takeoff - brief instrument scans only
Maintain centerline throughout roll and initial climb
Trim is essential for precise airspeed control

teachingScript.phase: Guided Practice - Student First Attempt (10 minutes)
instructorActions: Coach: 'Line up with centerline... add full power smoothly'
If student forgets rudder: Gently apply rudder and say 'Feel that? Right rudder as we accelerate'
Prompt: 'Airspeed is approaching rotation... ease back pressure'
Explain: 'If student rotates too early/late: Take controls and explain correction'
During climb: 'Check your airspeed... what do you notice?'
If more than 5 knots off VY: 'Adjust pitch slightly... there's VY'
Guide continuously: 'Let me help you refine this technique'
studentActions: Perform complete takeoff with instructor backup
Verbalize actions: 'Full power... watching centerline... rotate'
Maintain VY ±10 knots initially (tighten tolerance with practice)
keyPoints: It's normal to drift from centerline initially - prompt corrections
Airspeed control improves with practice - be patient
Positive, specific feedback: 'Good rudder input there!'
Safety first - instructor takes controls if necessary

instructorActions: Brief before takeoff: 'Wind is 20° off runway heading at 10 knots - here's my plan'
During lineup: 'Full aileron into the wind before starting roll'
Takeoff roll: 'Reducing aileron as speed increases... maintaining centerline with rudder'
Liftoff: 'Establishing crab angle immediately... see how I'm headed into the wind?'
Climb: 'Maintaining runway heading with coordinated flight... aileron neutral now'
Explain: 'Common mistake is fighting the wind instead of accepting the crab'
Guide continuously: 'Let me help you refine this technique'
studentActions: Observe control positions during crosswind takeoff
Ask questions about timing of control inputs
keyPoints: Aileron deflection decreases as speed increases
Crab into wind immediately after liftoff
Never let the airplane drift - maintain extended centerline
Rudder controls direction, ailerons prevent drift

instructorActions: Coach: 'Your airplane - you've got this'
Provide cues: 'Check altitude... perfect... maintain that'
Positive reinforcement: 'Excellent! That's exactly right'
Gentle corrections: 'A bit more back pressure... there'
Address errors: 'Let's discuss what happened and why'
Build confidence: 'Much smoother than your first attempt!'
Reduce assistance: 'Try this one with minimal help'
studentActions: Identify and correct instructor's deliberate errors
keyPoints: CFI candidates must both perform AND teach simultaneously
Recognizing errors in others sharpens your own performance
Clear, concise corrections are more effective than lengthy explanations

instructorActions: Welcome: 'Today's focus is normal takeoff and climb'
Ask: 'What do you know about normal takeoff and climb already?'
Instruct: 'Present objectives: Write clearly on whiteboard' with specific examples
Explain relevance: 'This is essential because...'
Instruct: 'Show references: POH, ACS, handbooks' with specific examples
Engage: 'Any questions before we start?'

keyPoints: ACS standards require VY ±5 knots - practice to exceed minimum
Teaching while flying requires extra mental capacity - builds with practice

keyTeachingPoints: Smooth power application prevents swerving and engine shock cooling
Right rudder is needed to counteract left-turning tendencies (P-factor, torque, spiraling slipstream, gyroscopic precession)
Rotate at proper speed - too early causes prolonged ground roll, too late risks tire/prop damage
VY provides best rate of climb - critical for obstacle clearance
Crosswind correction: Full aileron on ground, reduce as speed increases, crab after liftoff
Maintain extended runway centerline, not heading (±10°)
Trim for hands-off flight at VY
commonErrors: Inadequate right rudder during acceleration - airplane veers left - This compromises safety and learning effectiveness
Premature rotation - prolonged ground roll - This affects safety and performance
Delayed rotation - tire/prop damage risk - This affects safety and performance
Inadequate crosswind correction - drift off centerline - This compromises safety and learning effectiveness
Fixating on instruments - not maintaining outside reference - This affects safety and performance
Insufficient power application - poor acceleration - This leads to unsafe operations and poor learning outcomes
Poor trim usage - excessive control pressure - This leads to unsafe operations and poor learning outcomes
Inadequate clearing turns - collision hazard - This compromises safety and learning effectiveness

Video debriefs are incredibly effective for this task - student can see what they're doing

lessonPlans.title: Normal Approach and Landing
objectives: Maintain stabilized approach ±5 knots airspeed, ±100 feet altitude
Touch down in touchdown zone (first 1/3 of runway)
Demonstrate proper crosswind technique for wind conditions
Execute go-around if necessary before touchdown
references: FAA-H-8083-25 Pilot's Handbook of Aeronautical Knowledge
prerequisites: Student can maintain altitude and airspeed in level flight
Student has completed normal takeoff training
lessonPlans.overview: The normal approach and landing is the most frequently performed maneuver in aviation. This lesson covers the stabilized approach concept, energy management, wind correction, flare technique, and touchdown execution. Students learn to coordinate throttle, pitch, and trim while managing crosswind conditions and teaching simultaneously.

instructorActions: Brief clearly: 'Draw the approach profile: Downwind → Base → Final → Flare →'
Brief clearly: 'Explain stabilized approach criteria: On glidepath, on airsp'
Brief clearly: 'Demonstrate with model: Control inputs during crosswind land'
Discuss: 'The approach airspeed typically 1.3 Vso - for a Cessna 172, about 65 knots'
Brief clearly: 'Show POH landing performance charts'
Brief common errors: High/fast approaches, floating, porpoising, bouncing
Guide systematically: 'Let me help you refine this further'
keyPoints: Stabilized by 500 feet AGL is the goal
Pitch controls airspeed, power controls descent rate
Aim point should not move in windscreen

instructorActions: Narrate throughout: 'Turning base... reducing power... flaps 20'
Turn final: 'Aligning with centerline... establishing approach speed... full flaps'
On final: 'Airspeed 65 knots... aiming for the numbers... slight power adjustment'
Over threshold: 'Power to idle... eyes to far end of runway... gradual back pressure'
Flare: 'Hold it off... hold it off... there's the touchdown'
Rollout: 'Maintain centerline with rudder... elevator back... braking as needed'
Guide systematically: 'Let me help you refine this further'
keyPoints: Eyes transition from aim point to far end during flare
Main wheels touch first in tricycle gear

instructorActions: Coach: 'Turn final... what's your first action?'

During flare: Gently guide elevator if needed
After landing: 'Good centerline control!' or 'What could improve?'
Guide systematically: 'Let me help you refine this further'
studentActions: Self-announce at each point: 'Turning base', 'Final checklist complete'
keyPoints: First landings often have late flare - normal

instructorActions: Brief: 'We'll use the wing-low/crab method for crosswind'
Demonstrate: 'On final, crab into wind to maintain centerline'
Near touchdown: 'Transition to wing-low... upwind wing down, opposite rudder'
Touchdown: 'Upwind main wheel touches first... hold aileron into wind'
Rollout: 'Increase aileron deflection as we slow... maintain centerline'
Guide systematically: 'Let me help you refine this further'
Guide systematically: 'Let me help you refine this further'
keyPoints: Crab keeps you aligned with runway on approach
Never land in a crab - side loads damage gear
Full aileron deflection often needed at slow speeds

instructorActions: Ask: 'Which landing felt best? Why?'
Review: 'Your approach speeds were good, flare timing improving'
Address errors: 'On landing 3, what happened when you ballooned?'
Relate to ACS: 'Standard is touchdown within 400 feet of specified point'
Preview next lesson: 'We'll work on short-field landings next'
Guide systematically: 'Let me help you refine this further'
Guide systematically: 'Let me help you refine this further'
keyPoints: Landing is a perishable skill - practice regularly

keyTeachingPoints: Stabilized approach = consistent landings (on speed, on glide path, configured, aligned)
Pitch for airspeed, power for descent rate - primary/secondary effects (±10 knots)
Aim point shouldn't move in windscreen - if rising, too low; if falling, too high
Flare begins 10-20 feet AGL and is progressive - not one motion
Roundout → Hold off → Touchdown in three distinct phases
Crosswind: Crab on approach, transition to wing-low before touchdown
Go-around decision must be made before touchdown - never force a bad landing
After touchdown: Fly the airplane until it's parked and secured
commonErrors: Unstabilized approach - varying airspeeds and descent rates - This affects safety and performance
High approach - difficulty in landing in touchdown zone - This affects safety and performance
Low approach - risk of undershooting runway - This affects safety and performance
Fast approach - floating and long landing - This affects safety and performance
Slow approach - stall risk and hard landing - This affects safety and performance
Poor flare technique - hard landing or bounce - This leads to unsafe operations and poor learning outcomes
Inadequate crosswind correction - drift off centerline - This compromises safety and learning effectiveness
Delayed go-around decision - unsafe landing - This affects safety and performance

completionStandards.standard: Maintain stabilized approach
Touch down in touchdown zone
Maintain runway centerline
Demonstrate proper crosswind technique
Execute go-around if necessary

notes: First solo landings are often student's best - intense focus
Wind conditions vary lesson quality - calm for initial, crosswind for refinement
Every 10th landing should be a power-off (engine-out simulation)
suggestedHomework: Chair fly: Visualize complete pattern and landing sequence
Review POH: Landing performance charts, approach speeds
Calculate: Landing distance for various weights and conditions
Watch: Cockpit landing videos, critique technique
instructorNotes: Safety: Be ready to take controls during initial landings
Bounced landing: Go around unless minimal and correctable
Build student confidence with specific praise: 'Great centerline control on that one'
If student getting fatigued: Take a break or end lesson early
safetyConsiderations: Maintain situational awareness at all times

lessonPlans.title: Short-Field Takeoff and Maximum Performance Climb
objectives: Demonstrate short-field takeoff technique for obstacle clearance
Achieve VX for maximum angle of climb
Transition to VY after obstacle clearance
Identify and correct common short-field errors
lessonPlans.overview: Short-Field Takeoff and Maximum Performance Climb is an essential component of comprehensive flight instructor training. This meticulously designed lesson provides complete coverage of procedures, techniques, standards, and instructional methods necessary for professional-level instruction. Flight instructors develop both personal proficiency in execution and the pedagogical skills to teach effectively. The lesson integrates theoretical knowledge, practical application, safety considerations, risk management strategies, and assessment techniques. Through systematic progression from demonstration to coached practice to independent performance, students achieve mastery while simultaneously learning how to teach this material to future pilots.

instructorActions: Brief: 'Short-field takeoff gives maximum performance for obstacle clearance'
Instruct: 'Draw on whiteboard: Obstacle profile showing VX climb angle' with specific examples
Explain: 'VX is best angle of climb - steeper than VY'
Show POH: 'VX for this airplane is 62 knots'
Demonstrate with model: 'Position at very start of runway'
Brief technique: 'Brakes on, full power, check instruments, release brakes'
Discuss: 'We rotate 5 knots below VX for better ground acceleration'
keyPoints: Use every inch of available runway

instructorActions: Taxi to absolute start of runway: 'Using every foot available'
Set brakes: 'Brakes set, full power coming'
Smoothly apply full power: 'Full throttle... checking engine instruments'
Release brakes: 'Brakes released, accelerating'
Rotate: 'Approaching rotation speed... ease back'
After liftoff: 'Establishing VX... 62 knots precisely'
Clear obstacle: 'Obstacle cleared by 50 feet... accelerating to VY'
studentActions: See transition from VX to VY
keyPoints: Rotation at VX-5 knots optimizes ground acceleration
Transition to VY after obstacle cleared

instructorActions: Coach: 'Position at the very start... set brakes'
During power application: 'Smooth to full power... check your gauges'
If airspeed deviation: 'Check your pitch... VX is 62 knots'
After obstacle: 'Good! Now accelerate to VY for better climb rate'
Debrief each attempt: 'That clearance was 75 feet - excellent margin'
Build proficiency: 'Each one is getting more precise'
Guide continuously: 'Let me help you refine this technique'
keyPoints: Precision in airspeed critical for safety

keyTeachingPoints: Short-field takeoff maximizes performance for obstacle clearance

Clear obstacle by 50 feet minimum per ACS

objectives: Touch down at minimum controllable airspeed

lessonPlans.overview: Short-Field Approach and Landing is an essential flight maneuver requiring both technical proficiency and instructional excellence. This elite-level lesson provides comprehensive coverage of all procedures, techniques, standards, common errors, and professional teaching methods. Flight instructors develop not only the ability to execute the maneuver perfectly to ACS standards, but also the pedagogical skills to teach effectively, recognize student difficulties, provide specific corrective feedback, and assess readiness for solo or practical test. The lesson integrates aeronautical decision-making, risk management, and safety considerations throughout, preparing CFI candidates for professional-level instruction.

objectives: Establish and maintain 45° bank angle ±5° within 3 seconds of entry
Maintain altitude ±100 feet throughout turn with maximum 50 feet loss during entry/recovery
Maintain airspeed ±10 knots with power adjustment of 100-200 RPM above cruise

lessonPlans.overview:
Steep Turns is an essential flight maneuver that CFI candidates must master both in execution and instruction. This comprehensive lesson covers the complete procedure from preflight planning through post-flight debrief, emphasizing ACS standards, safety considerations, and effective teaching techniques. 

TECHNICAL SPECIFICATIONS:
• Bank Angle: 45° ±5° established within 3 seconds
• Altitude: ±100 feet throughout, maximum 50 feet loss during entry/recovery
• Airspeed: ±10 knots with power adjustment 100-200 RPM above cruise
• Heading: ±10° rollout with 22-23° lead angle
• Load Factor: 1.41 G at 45° bank, stall speed increases 20%

SAFETY CONSIDERATIONS:
• Minimum altitude 3000 AGL for practice
• 90° clearing turns required before entry
• Continuous traffic scan throughout maneuver
• Monitor for uncoordinated flight and spatial disorientation
• Verify student understanding of load factor effects

Instructors will learn how to demonstrate the maneuver proficiently while simultaneously providing clear instruction, recognize and correct common student errors, and assess student readiness for solo flight or practical test.

commonErrors: Teaching risk management as academic topic only - This affects safety and performance
Not integrating risk management into flight lessons - This affects safety and performance
Instructor not modeling good risk management - This affects safety and performance

Not using real-world scenarios for risk assessment practice - This affects safety and performance
Teaching memorization of acronyms without application - This affects safety and performance
Not discussing accidents/incidents as learning opportunities - This affects safety and performance
Allowing student to take unnecessary risks - This affects safety and performance
Not assessing student's risk management during checkride prep - This affects safety and performance
Treating risk management as checkbook for compliance, not safety tool - This affects safety and performance

completionStandards.standard: Use scenario-based training (SBT) to demonstrate, teach, and assess risk management and Aeronautical Decision-Making (ADM) skills in the context of a Task specified by the evaluator.
Identify, assess, and mitigate risks commonly associated with flight instruction by maintaining:
a. Awareness and oversight of the learner’s actions, with timely and appropriate supervision, intervention, or mitigation as needed
b. Awareness of the learner’s cognitive/physiological state, with timely action to mitigate anxiety, fatigue, or other obstruction to learning
c. Overall situational awareness of the aircraft’s dynamic state, its position in space, and vigilance for unexpected events or changing circumstances that occur in the environment
Model and teach safety practices, including maintaining:
a. Collision avoidance while simultaneously providing instruction
b. Avoidance of unnecessary distractions
c. Coordinated flight
d. Awareness of who is manipulating controls through positive exchange of flight controls

Continuing flight when factors compound beyond capability - This affects safety and performance

keyTeachingPoints: Visual scanning essential for collision avoidance
Most midair collisions occur during daylight, clear weather, near airports
See and avoid is pilot's primary responsibility
Empty-field myopia: Eyes relax to 10-30 feet when no objects to focus on
Effective scan: Divide sky into sectors, focus on each sector 1-2 seconds
Peripheral vision detects motion - direct vision identifies objects
Relative motion indicates collision course - object not moving in windscreen
Clearing turns before maneuvers, climbs, descents critical
commonErrors: Not scanning outside cockpit - fixation on instruments - This affects safety and performance
Inadequate clearing before maneuvers - This compromises safety and learning effectiveness
Scanning too quickly without focusing on sectors - This affects safety and performance
Not accounting for blind spots caused by aircraft structure - This affects safety and performance
Assuming ATC or technology will prevent collision - This affects safety and performance
Not looking for traffic in traffic pattern - This affects safety and performance
Failure to make radio position reports - This can result in loss of aircraft control
Not seeing traffic that ATC has pointed out - This affects safety and performance
Staring at one spot (empty-field myopia) - This affects safety and performance
Not adjusting scan for different phases of flight - This affects safety and performance

completionStandards.standard: Effectively scan using short regularly spaced eye movements.
Scan around physical obstructions.
Use appropriate visual scanning techniques.
Use electronic traffic alert systems, if available.

keyTeachingPoints: Runway incursion: Unauthorized aircraft/vehicle/person on runway
Leading cause: Pilot deviations during taxi operations
Read back all runway crossing/hold short clearances
Never cross hold short line without explicit clearance
Airport signs: Red = stop, yellow = caution, black on yellow = location
Airport markings: Yellow taxi lines, runway hold short markings
Enhanced taxiway centerline marking at high-risk intersections
Write down taxi instructions (or have copilot/CFI write them)
commonErrors: Not reading back hold short instructions - This affects safety and performance
Crossing hold short line without clearance - This affects safety and performance
Confusion about which runway cleared to cross - This affects safety and performance
Not knowing aircraft position on airport - This affects safety and performance
Accepting clearance when unsure of taxi route - This affects safety and performance
Distraction during taxi - heads down in cockpit - This affects safety and performance
Night operations without adequate preparation - This affects safety and performance
Not using airport diagram during taxi - This affects safety and performance
Assuming clearance when instructions unclear - This affects safety and performance
Failure to ask for progressive taxi when needed - This can result in loss of aircraft control

keyTeachingPoints: National Airspace System: Complex system of airspace classifications
Class A: 18,000 MSL to FL600, IFR only, clearance required
Class B: Busy airports, surface to 10,000 MSL, clearance required, Mode C
Class C: Medium airports, surface to 4,000 AGL, two-way radio, Mode C
Class D: Towered airports, surface to 2,500 AGL, two-way radio required
Class E: Controlled airspace not A/B/C/D, IFR traffic control
Class G: Uncontrolled airspace, pilot responsible for separation
Special Use Airspace: Prohibited, Restricted, Warning, MOA, Alert
commonErrors: Entering Class B without clearance - This affects safety and performance
Not establishing two-way radio in Class C/D - This affects safety and performance
Violating weather minimums for airspace - This affects safety and performance
Not checking NOTAMs for TFRs - This affects safety and performance
Flying through restricted area without authorization - This affects safety and performance
Operating without Mode C in airspace requiring it - This affects safety and performance
Not understanding cloud clearance requirements - This affects safety and performance
Entering Class D when tower closed (becomes Class E) - This affects safety and performance
Confusion about surface vs. floor of airspace - This affects safety and performance
Not maintaining VFR visibility requirements - This affects safety and performance

completionStandards.standard: Identify and comply with the requirements for basic VFR weather minimums and flying in particular classes of airspace.
Correctly identify airspace and operate in accordance with associated communication and equipment requirements.
Identify the requirements for operating in SUA or within a TFR. Identify and comply with special air traffic rules (SATR) and SFRA operations, if applicable.

lessonPlans.title: Soft-Field Takeoff and Climb
objectives: Establish VX precisely +5/-0 knots per ACS
Clear obstacle by 50 feet minimum per ACS
Accelerate to VY after obstacle cleared ±5 knots
Use recommended flap setting per POH
Demonstrate proper technique for short-field conditions
lessonPlans.overview: Soft-field takeoffs are essential for operations from grass, mud, snow, or unpaved surfaces. This lesson teaches techniques to minimize weight on the landing gear and use ground effect to accelerate before climbing.

instructorActions: Welcome: 'Today's focus is soft-field takeoff and climb'
Ask: 'What do you know about soft-field takeoff and climb already?'
Explain: 'Present objectives: Write clearly on whiteboard'
Explain relevance: 'This is essential because...'
Show references: POH, ACS, handbooks
Engage: 'Any questions before we start?'
Preview: 'By the end, you'll be able to demonstrate soft-field takeoff and climb'
studentActions: Take organized notes on key concepts
keyPoints: Continuous motion - don't stop on soft surface
Elevator back during taxi and takeoff roll
Early liftoff uses ground effect advantage

instructorActions: Set stage: 'Watch everything I do during soft-field takeoff and climb'
Narrate constantly: 'Checking airspeed 90 knots... adding power now'
Call out senses: 'Feel the back pressure? Hear the engine note?'
Show references: 'This horizon picture is what you want to see'
Execute perfectly: Demonstrate to ACS standards while talking
Highlight errors: 'Students often forget to... watch how I remember'
Debrief immediately: 'What were the three key things you noticed?'
Coach actively: 'You're doing soft-field takeoff and climb - talk me through it'
Provide real-time cues: 'Check airspeed... perfect... hold that altitude'
Praise progress: 'Much better! Your technique is improving each attempt'
Correct immediately: 'A bit more rudder... there, coordinated now'
Ask questions: 'What should you be watching right now?'
Build awareness: 'Feel how the controls respond? Remember that sensation'
Gradual release: 'This attempt, I'm only here if you need me'
studentActions: Perform soft-field takeoff and climb with decreasing instructor assistance
keyPoints: Gradual reduction of coaching builds independence

instructorActions: Coach: 'Your airplane - you've got this'

objectives: Entry at maneuvering speed (VA) or cruise ±5 knots

lessonPlans.overview:
Chandelles is an advanced flight maneuver that demonstrates energy management and precise aircraft control. This comprehensive lesson covers the complete procedure from preflight planning through post-flight debrief, emphasizing ACS standards, safety considerations, and effective teaching techniques.

TECHNICAL SPECIFICATIONS:
• Entry Speed: VA or cruise ±5 knots
• Bank Angle: 30° ±5° maintained throughout first 90°
• Maximum Pitch: 20-25° ±5° at 90° point
• Maximum Altitude: Reached at 180° point (not 90°)
• Minimum Airspeed: 5-10 knots above stall at 180° point
• Heading: ±10° rollout accuracy
• Altitude Gain: Typically 200-400 feet

SAFETY CONSIDERATIONS:
• Minimum altitude 3000 AGL for practice
• Continuous traffic scan throughout maneuver
• Monitor for stall at 180° point
• Verify student understanding of energy management
• Ensure coordinated flight throughout

Instructors will learn how to demonstrate the maneuver proficiently while simultaneously providing clear instruction, recognize and correct common student errors, and assess student readiness for solo flight or practical test.
